content: The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" is introduced to exclude space-related income from gross income according to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" excludes space-related income from gross income as defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Space-related income includes income derived from products or services produced or provided in outer space. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" excludes income from products or services produced or provided in outer space from gross income as defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes income from services performed in outer space, as well as interest, rent, royalty, or similar amounts related to space production or services. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" excludes income from services performed in outer space, as well as interest, rent, royalty, or similar amounts related to space production or services. Telecommunications services provided from earth orbit and services from weather or earth observation satellites are exceptions to this rule. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" excludes income from services performed in outer space, as well as interest, rent, royalty, or similar amounts related to space production or services. Exceptions include telecommunications services from earth orbit, services from weather or earth observation satellites, and transporting property to or from outer space before the enactment of this section. Wages received by employees are also exempt from this rule. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" excludes income from services performed in outer space, including transporting property to or from outer space. Wages received by employees are exempt from this rule. Space-related income is proportionally allocated for products produced partly in space. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" excludes income from services performed in outer space, including transporting property to or from outer space. Space-related income is proportionally allocated for products produced partly in space, with the term "produced" encompassing various activities. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" excludes income from services in outer space and transporting property to or from there. It proportionally allocates space-related income for products partly produced in space, with "produced" including various activities like manufacturing and processing. Products manufactured in outer space are excluded from tariffs if launched from or manufactured at a facility in space. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" exempts products manufactured in outer space from federal tariffs if launched from or manufactured at a facility owned by US persons in space. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" exempts products manufactured in outer space from federal tariffs if launched from or manufactured at a facility owned by US persons in space. Starting from 2015, the amount excluded from taxes will gradually decrease based on the number of years after 2014. Starting from December 31, 2014, the excluded amount under subsection (a) will decrease by x/10th's of the amount excludable without this rule, where 'x' is the number of years after 2015. A similar reduction applies to benefits under subsection (c). A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for part III of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2005. A new section, "SEC. 45J. SPACE COMPANY INVESTMENT CREDIT," is added to the Internal Revenue Code for a credit on qualified space company stock purchases. The new section "SEC. 45J. SPACE COMPANY INVESTMENT CREDIT" in the Internal Revenue Code allows for a credit on qualified stock purchases in a domestic C corporation with average annual gross receipts not exceeding $100,000,000. A qualified space company is defined as a domestic C corporation with average annual gross receipts not exceeding $100,000,000, and more than 70 percent of gross receipts derived from space-based business. Space-based business refers to income related to space activities. Qualified stock, for the purposes of this section, refers to any stock in a domestic C corporation that meets the criteria outlined, including being a qualified space company with specific gross receipts and space-based business income requirements. Rules similar to section 1202(d)(3) apply for aggregation in section 139B(b)(3) regarding qualified stock in a domestic C corporation. Qualified stock is defined as stock in a qualified space company acquired at original issue by the taxpayer. Qualified stock in a domestic C corporation is defined as stock in a qualified space company acquired at original issue by the taxpayer, either in exchange for money or other property, or as compensation for services provided. Qualified stock in a domestic C corporation is defined as stock acquired at original issue by the taxpayer in exchange for money, property, or as compensation for services provided. The corporation must meet active business requirements during the taxpayer's holding period for the stock. During the taxpayer's holding period, qualified stock in a C corporation must meet active business requirements similar to section 1202(e) for a space-based business and be a C corporation. During the taxpayer's holding period, qualified stock in a C corporation must meet active business requirements similar to section 1202(e) for a space-based business. Rules similar to section 1202(c)(3) apply to the purchase of its own stock by the corporation. If the issuer of the qualified stock ceases to be a qualified space company within 10 years, recapture rules apply for tax purposes. Rules similar to section 1202(c)(3) apply to qualified stock purchased by the taxpayer. If the issuer of the stock ceases to be a qualified space company within 10 years, tax recapture rules apply. This section does not apply to stock acquired after December 31, 2013. The section allows for a credit determined under subsection (a) to be reduced to zero for stock acquired before December 31, 2013. This credit is part of the general business credit under Section 38(b) of the Code. The amendment to Section 38(b) of the Code adds a new paragraph for space company investment credit. Subsection (c) of Section 196 is also amended to include this new credit. The amendment adds a new space company investment credit to Section 196 of the Code. The amendment introduces a Space Company Investment Credit under Section 196 of the Code, effective for costs incurred after December 31, 2005. Additionally, a Capital Gains Exclusion is added for gains from the sale or exchange of stock of Qualified Space Corporations under Section 1203 of the Internal Revenue Code. Gross income excludes gain from selling stock of a qualified space corporation, defined as a domestic C corporation providing products or services in outer space. A qualified space corporation must be organized exclusively for providing products or services in outer space, with at least 90 percent of expenses related to this activity. A qualified space corporation must be organized exclusively for providing products or services in outer space, with at least 90 percent of expenses related to this activity. The corporation should not provide services, products, or articles described in section 139B(b)(2). The exclusion for gains from the sale or exchange of stock of qualified space corporations is effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2005.
